text: Going long oil after a Trump win is an interesting strategy. I would have gone the opposite way, based on likely increases in US production and Trump’s previous involvement with the Abraham accords. Time will tell.

elements.text: Going long oil after a Trump win is an interesting strategy. I would have gone the opposite way, based on likely increases in US production and Trump’s previous involvement with the Abraham accords. Time will tell.

text: I wasn't looking at Nate's work. I was looking at a bunch of analysis, but mostly 538 which he founded _but has no involvement in any more_. It's owned by ABC News, and uses methods that he started work on back in 2006-2008, but has been iterated on an improved every year since. I've been saying consistently that the result falls within the published error bars, just at the edge of those bars. The polling was skewed off to the left for reasons unknown (it now seems to be a mixture of "shy" Trump voters and sampling errors - again - which means like a good Bayesian next cycle I'll accept that information to update my prior), meaning those who skewed the market hard to the right were on this occasion correct, but given the public information known at the time, creating EV opportunities for those of us willing to be counter-parties.

attachments.text:
so the french guy who yolo’d $30m on trump on polymarket noticed polls asking “who are your neighbors voting for?” instead of “who are you voting for?” had trump overperforming.

so he commissioned his own poll to confirm.

$49m profit in a week.
attachments.title: Siqi Chen (@blader) on X

text: 538, the silver bulletin, etc represent the public information as much as the racing post probably represent the public information for a horse race. if the bsp was massively different to the RP forecast on lots of volume I think most of us would on balance conclude that there might be a crazy owner who's really stupid, orr someones got a better model than the RP or better information.

text:
I am personally active in politics and political campaigns in the UK. The "shy Tory" - or in this case "shy Trump" effect is very well known in these circles. It has played out in most (perhaps not all, but definitely most) UK election polls in the last 40 years.

I don't know why polling companies haven't learnt their lesson, but they haven't. People lie, and they lie in a fairly systematic way (the effect size varies over time but the direction generally does not).

I have no doubt that there were +EV bets to be made on this election, but they could only have been made by someone who has very carefully studied the "shy" effect with data, and I suspect very few of us here have. Theo did, and his data gave him confidence that his bets were +EV, so he placed them - probably he got the Kelly staking wrong but the EV was there.

The idea that Harris was +EV at 2.x based on "the available information" is highly likely to be wrong (though I admit I cannot be 100% of this, having not studied the data in detail) because the available information included a long and predictable history of exactly this sort of polling error.

I am personally active in politics and political campaigns in the UK. The "shy Tory" - or in this case "shy Trump" effect is very well known in these circles. It has played out in most (perhaps not all, but definitely most) UK election polls in the last 40 years.

I don't know why polling companies haven't learnt their lesson, but they haven't. People lie, and they lie in a fairly systematic way (the effect size varies over time but the direction generally does not).

I have no doubt that there were +EV bets to be made on this election, but they could only have been made by someone who has very carefully studied the "shy" effect with data, and I suspect very few of us here have. Theo did, and his data gave him confidence that his bets were +EV, so he placed them - probably he got the Kelly staking wrong but the EV was there.

The idea that Harris was +EV at 2.x based on "the available information" is highly likely to be wrong (though I admit I cannot be 100% of this, having not studied the data in detail) because the available information included a long and predictable history of exactly this sort of polling error.

text: Fwiw, if you consider something to have odds of a coin toss, it may also mean that your model/forecast is no better than a coin toss (i.e. you got no alpha, as opposed to strong alpha that is confident it is indeed a coin toss)

elements.text: Fwiw, if you consider something to have odds of a coin toss, it may also mean that your model/forecast is no better than a coin toss (i.e. you got no alpha, as opposed to strong alpha that is confident it is indeed a coin toss)

text: I’ll hold my hands up, the analysis he did with neighbour polls is absolutely inspired, it’s something to learn from, and explains away much of the EV I thought they were giving the rest of us (but maybe not quite Harris at 2.7…). I think I had assumed somewhat that the aggregations and skews were taking that shy Trump factor into effect better than they were - something to watch out for more in the future.
